# Appendix B: Anticommutation of impurity and tip with the chirality operator 

The main ingredient required to observe a winding difference between two Dirac cones, as in section III, is an impurity and/or STM tip which favors one chirality over the other. We can consider the definition of the chiral basis

to write the expectation values, in Eq. (32), in terms of the eigenstates of the Hamiltonian, Eq. (1), as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle A_{K_{i}}\right| \hat{M}\left|A_{K_{j}}\right\rangle=\frac{\left\langle n_{K_{i}}\right| \hat{M}\left|n_{K_{j}}\right\rangle}{2}+\frac{\left\langle n_{K_{i}}\right| \Gamma^{-1} \hat{M} \Gamma\left|n_{K_{j}}\right\rangle}{2}+\frac{\left\langle n_{K_{i}}\right|\left(\Gamma^{-1} \hat{M}+\hat{M} \Gamma\right)\left|n_{K_{j}}\right\rangle}{2} \\
& \left\langle B_{K_{i}}\right| \hat{M}\left|B_{K_{j}}\right\rangle=\frac{\left\langle n_{K_{i}}\right| \hat{M}\left|n_{K_{j}}\right\rangle}{2}+\frac{\left\langle n_{K_{i}}\right| \Gamma^{-1} \hat{M} \Gamma\left|n_{K_{j}}\right\rangle}{2}-\frac{\left\langle n_{K_{i}}\right|\left(\Gamma^{-1} \hat{M}+\hat{M} \Gamma\right)\left|n_{K_{j}}\right\rangle}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where it is clear that if $\left\langle n_{K_{i}}\right|\left(\Gamma^{-1} \hat{M}+\hat{M} \Gamma\right)\left|n_{K_{j}}\right\rangle=0$ the two terms are equal. By considering the commutation of the impurity and tip with the chirality operator $\Gamma$ it is clear that if $\{\Gamma, \hat{M}\}=0$, then $\Gamma^{-1} \hat{M} \Gamma=-\hat{M}$ and:

$$
\left\langle A_{K_{i}}\right| \hat{M}\left|A_{K_{j}}\right\rangle=\left\langle B_{K_{i}}\right| \hat{M}\left|B_{K_{j}}\right\rangle=0
$$

However, if $\Gamma^{-1} \hat{M} \Gamma=\hat{M}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle A_{K_{i}}\right| \hat{M}\left|A_{K_{j}}\right\rangle=\left\langle n_{K_{i}}\right| \hat{M}\left|n_{K_{j}}\right\rangle+\left\langle n_{K_{i}}\right| \hat{M} \Gamma\left|n_{K_{j}}\right\rangle \\
& \left\langle B_{K_{i}}\right| \hat{M}\left|B_{K_{j}}\right\rangle=\left\langle n_{K_{i}}\right| \hat{M}\left|n_{K_{j}}\right\rangle-\left\langle n_{K_{i}}\right| \hat{M} \Gamma\left|n_{K_{j}}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

To have chirality-selective terms we thus require that the operator $\hat{M}$ or $\hat{V}$ conserve the chiral symmetry as well as that the eigenstates at the nodes yield a non-zero expectation value for both operators $\hat{M}$ and $\hat{M} \Gamma$.

# Appendix C: Details for $\mathbf{N b S e}_{2}$
## 1. Chiral basis and projection procedure, illustrated on the example of $\mathbf{N b S e}_{2}$

We observe that the off-diagonal form of a chiral Hamiltonian in Eq. 5 does not fix the $Q$-matrix uniquely. Considering a generic choice for $Q$, there are two key issues: (1) $Q$ is non-Hermitian, so there is no guarantee of an orthogonal set of right eigenvectors $\left\{\left|A_{n}\right\rangle\right\}$ of $Q$, and an orthogonal set of right eigenvectors $\left\{\left|B_{n}\right\rangle\right\}$ of $Q^{\dagger}$ such that an eigenstate of the Hamiltonian $\left|\alpha\right\rangle$ is a simple combination of $\left|A_{\alpha}\right\rangle$ and $\left|B_{\alpha}\right\rangle$; (2) The amplitudes $\left|\xi_{\alpha}\right|$ of the eigenvalues of $Q$ may differ by a constant prefactor from the energies $E_{\alpha}$. We note that the second point is usually circumvented in discussion of topology by flattening the Hamiltonian so that $E_{\alpha}= \pm 1$.

Let us illustrate these issues in the case of the model of $\mathrm{NbSe}_{2}$ used in Section IV. The Hamiltonian is written in an off-diagonal form

$$
\mathcal{H}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & Q_{t} \\
Q_{t}^{\dagger} & 0
\end{array}\right)
$$

with the particular matrix

$$
Q_{t}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}} & h+i \lambda_{\boldsymbol{k}}-\Delta \\
h-i \lambda_{\boldsymbol{k}}+\Delta & \epsilon_{\boldsymbol{k}}
\end{array}\right)
$$

by using the unitary transformation $U=e^{-i \frac{\pi}{4} \tau_{y}} e^{-i \frac{\pi}{4} \sigma_{x} \tau_{z}}$ given in Ref. [39]. The $Q_{t}$ matrix is obviously non-Hermitian, its right eigenvectors are not orthogonal, and its eigenvalues do not give the correct bands. We hence consider an additional unitary transformation by which the $Q$-matrix is rescaled:

$$
\mathcal{H}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & Q \\
Q^{\dagger} & 0
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & S Q_{t} \\
Q_{t}^{\dagger} S^{\dagger} & 0
\end{array}\right)
$$

with

$$
S=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\sqrt{\frac{h+\Delta}{h-\Delta}} & 0 \\
0 & \sqrt{\frac{h-\Delta}{h+\Delta}}
\end{array}\right)
$$

so that the amplitudes of eigenvalues $\left|\xi_{\boldsymbol{k}}\right|$ equal the bands $|E(\boldsymbol{k})|$. Although the $Q$-matrix is still non-Hermitian, its right eigenbasis is orthogonal. The reason is that the diagonalized $Q$-matrix now indeed looks like Eq. 6 (the $\left.\left|\xi_{\boldsymbol{k}}\right|=|E(\boldsymbol{k})|\right)$, and its individual eigenvectors $\left\{\left|A_{n}\right\rangle\right\}$ must directly give the individual eigenvectors of the Hamiltonian.

We are therefore equipped with a good choice of $Q$-matrix (and hence $Q^{\dagger}$ ) that produces the $\xi_{\boldsymbol{k}}$ and $\left\{\left|A_{n}\right\rangle,\left|B_{n}\right\rangle\right\}$ useful for calculating the LDOS in a chiral system.

The next important technical issue is that we wish to project the Green's function into the band that forms the cone $(n=1)$, neglecting the gapped high-energy bands $(n>1)$. The problem arises since the above basis $\left\{\left|A_{n}\right\rangle,\left|B_{n}\right\rangle\right\}$ is still not unique, we can change the phases of vectors. In particular, since the node winding number only fixes the total sum of windings of the phases $\sum_{n} \theta_{n}(\boldsymbol{k})$, we may reshuffle the non-trivial winding between the different bands $n$. The projection to $n=1$ may therefore remove some winding contributions from the Green's function. A similar problem has been identified and studied in depth in recent years in systems where projecting to low-energy tight-binding bands non-trivially affects the gauge invariance of the model of matter coupled to light, e.g., in cavity systems. The considerations of different schemes inspire us to choose a procedure where we redefine the basis so that all the $\theta_{n>1}(\boldsymbol{k})$ are trivial, hence shifting all the winding into the cone band $n=1$. (Physically, it is an intuitively appealing situation that a gapped band in vicinity of a node does not contain any singularities of $\theta(\boldsymbol{k})$.) Hence in this work the final form of the basis is fixed by this requirement, and in particular in Section IV the winding of the gapped band $W_{2}=0$. We finally note that a full (numerical) calculation of the Green's function including the gapped bands, without projection, may be used to confirm the validity of the projection procedure.

Explicitly, for the model introduced in Section IV, nodes for the inner $K_{i, \beta=-1}$ and outer $K_{i, \beta=+1}$ pockets at the FS occur at $\lambda_{k}=0$, so that the chiral basis in this case is the same for all nodal points on the same pocket:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|A_{K_{i, \beta}}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2^{3 / 2}}\left(-i \sqrt{1-\frac{\Delta}{h}}\left(c_{y, k}+c_{y,-k}^{\dagger}\right)-\beta \sqrt{1+\frac{\Delta}{h}}\left(c_{-y, k}-c_{-y,-k}^{\dagger}\right)\right) \\
\left|B_{K_{i, \beta}}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2^{3 / 2}}\left(\beta \sqrt{1-\frac{\Delta}{h}}\left(c_{-y, k}+c_{-y,-k}^{\dagger}\right)-i \sqrt{1+\frac{\Delta}{h}}\left(c_{y, k}-c_{y,-k}^{\dagger}\right)\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

where $c_{ \pm y, k}=c_{\mp, k} \pm i c_{\downarrow, k}$. In general, the chiral basis will be different for each point $K_{i}$. In this system however we can set $\left|A_{K_{i, \beta}}\right\rangle=\left|A_{\beta}\right\rangle,\left|B_{K_{i, \beta}}\right\rangle=\left|B_{\beta}\right\rangle$. To gain an understanding of how an impurity scatters between states in the chiral basis we consider the form that a non-magnetic impurity takes in the basis: $\tilde{V}_{0}=\sigma_{0} \otimes \tau_{z}=\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{\Delta}{h}\right)^{2}} \tilde{\sigma}_{0} \otimes \tilde{\tau}_{x}-\frac{\Delta}{h} \tilde{\sigma}_{y} \otimes \tilde{\tau}_{y}$. Here $\tilde{\sigma}_{i}, \tilde{\tau}_{i}$ are Pauli matrices for $\beta$ labels within a $A$ - or $B$-state and for the $A, B$-labels respectively. The non-magnetic impurity thus scatters equally within both $A, B$-states, as well as between them.

# 2. Cancellation of scattering term 

For the choice of impurity and STM tip in section IV A there is an additional non-zero matrix element between $A$ and $B$ states,

$$
\left\langle A_{\beta} \mid \tilde{V}_{x} \mid B_{\beta}\right\rangle=0, \quad\left\langle A_{\beta}\right| \tilde{M}_{x}\left|B_{\beta}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2}, \quad\left\langle A_{\beta}\right| \tilde{M}_{y}\left|B_{\beta}\right\rangle=0
$$

for nodes on the same Fermi surface. There is thus an additional type of scattering term that must be considered:

$$
\delta \rho_{01}=\operatorname{Re}\left[e^{\boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{K} \cdot \boldsymbol{r}} M_{B} T_{B}\left(\operatorname{Im}\left[i H_{0}\left(\frac{\omega r}{v}\right) H_{1}\left(\frac{\omega r}{v}\right)\right]\left[\frac{M_{A B}}{M_{B}}\left(e^{i \theta_{K_{i}}}-e^{-i \theta_{K_{j}}} \chi_{V}\right)-\frac{M_{B A}}{M_{B}}\left(e^{i \theta_{K_{j}}}-e^{-i \theta_{K_{i}}} \chi_{V}\right)\right]\right)\right]
$$

For this example system all $\chi_{i}$ are real, with $\chi_{V}=1$, so assuming the same anisotropy of both nodes:

$$
\delta \rho_{01}=\operatorname{Re}\left[e^{\boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{K} \cdot \boldsymbol{r}} h_{01}(r) M_{B} T_{B} \chi_{A B, M} \sqrt{\frac{2}{1+\alpha^{2}}} 2\left(\cos \left(w_{K_{i}} \theta_{k}+\phi_{K_{i}}\right)-\cos \left(w_{K_{j}} \theta_{k}+\phi_{K_{j}}\right)\right)\right]
$$

where $\chi_{A B, M}=\frac{M_{A B}}{M_{B}}=\frac{M_{B A}}{M_{B}}$. As $\delta \rho_{01, \Delta K}=-\delta \rho_{01,-\Delta K}$ for any pair of nodes, these terms cancel in the full scattering expression.

## 3. Size of sample and resolution

The number of wavefronts that are observed in an experiment will depend on the wavelength of the Friedel oscillations $\lambda_{\Delta K}=2 \pi /|\Delta K|$. The more wavefronts observed the better the resolution of the Fourier transform is. The most

![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

FIG. 6. For $\mathrm{NbSe}_{2}$ under an in-plane field at $\omega=0.01$ and an impurity $M_{x}=0.1 M_{y}$. a) LDOS b) phase information of FFT when in a $100 \times 100$ window. c) The wavefronts are shown for 2 adjacent points, from the calculation in a), one in black and another in red. If the wavelengths are much larger than the difference between them, the calculation cannot clearly distinguish between the 2 overlapping discontinuities.
promising points to study are therefore those separated by a large $\boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{K}$. This wavelength is not affected by which energy $\omega$ an experiment is carried out at. However, there is an energy dependence of the Hankel functions in $h_{i}(r, \omega)$. Thus, the regions in which the conditions are met shifts to a greater $r$ as the energy $\omega$ is lowered.

In Fig. 6 the calculation for $\mathrm{NbSe}_{2}$, shown in Fig. 2, for a $100 \times 100$ window. As the unit cell has $a=4.3 \AA$ this corresponds to a $43 \times 43 \mathrm{~nm}$ window. For this size the resolution is not enough to determine the winding around each point for two adjacent scattering vectors. However, since adjacent vectors carry the same vorticity, a non-trivial winding can be observed even in a small system.

In contrast, let us consider the observation in real space. A path encompassing two scattering vectors, each with a winding $\Delta W=2$, has a combined $\Delta W_{+}+\Delta W_{-}=4$. In real space, Fig. 6c shows that for two scattering vectors of similar size $\boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{K}_{-} \approx \boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{K}_{+}$the system size might not be sufficient to distinguish between the two wavefronts, and the data cannot clearly distinguish between the two overlapping discontinuities. Consequently, even though a non-trivial vortex around both vectors $\boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{K}_{-}, \boldsymbol{\Delta} \boldsymbol{K}_{+}$can be observed in momentum space of a smaller system, clearly observing $\Delta W_{+}+\Delta W_{-}$in real space requires a better resolution.

This reinforces our discussion of momentum space vortices being more robust observables than real-space dislocations.

## Appendix D: Weak scattering potential approximation for Fe impurity in nodal superconductor $\mathbf{N b S e}_{2}$

The Born approximation entails neglecting the dimensionless term $V G_{0}$ in the denominator of the $\hat{T}$-matrix, which more precisely takes the form:

$$
\hat{T}(\omega)=\left[\mathbb{1}-\hat{V} \int \frac{d \boldsymbol{k}}{\left(\frac{2 \pi}{b}\right)^{2}} \hat{G}_{0}(\boldsymbol{k}, \omega)\right]^{-1} \hat{V}
$$

Note that we recovered the dimensions by regularizing on a lattice, using the tight-binding lattice of $\mathrm{NbSe}_{2}$, with $b=\sqrt{3} a_{0}$, where the lattice constant $a_{0}=3.44 \AA$. The $\hat{V}$ has dimensions of energy, and acts on a single lattice site $(\boldsymbol{r}=0)$, while the Green's function $\hat{G}_{0}$ of the cone in the continuum multiplied by $b^{2}$ becomes the lattice Green's function. An alternative viewpoint is that in the continuum the impurity potential energy term is $\hat{V}_{\text {cont }} \delta(\boldsymbol{r})$, with $\hat{V}_{\text {cont }}$ having units of energy times area, and in the lattice regularization becomes $\hat{V}_{\text {cont }} \rightarrow \hat{V} b^{2}$, with energy scale $\hat{V}$ multiplied by the unit-cell area.

To proceed with at least a rough quantitative estimate, we replace the Green's function by the trace of its imaginary part, $\hat{G}_{0} \rightarrow \operatorname{Tr} \operatorname{Im} \hat{G}_{0}$, so that:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int \frac{d \boldsymbol{k}}{\left(\frac{2 \pi}{b}\right)^{2}} \hat{G}_{0}(\boldsymbol{k}, \omega)=b^{2} \hat{G}_{0}(\boldsymbol{r}=0, \omega) \rightarrow \\
& \rightarrow b^{2} \operatorname{Tr} \operatorname{Im} \hat{G}_{0}(\boldsymbol{r}=0, \omega)=\pi b^{2} \operatorname{DOS}(\omega)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\operatorname{DOS}(\omega)$ is the uniform density of states (with units of inverse energy and inverse area) at energy $\omega$ within the cone. We note that the dimensionless number $b^{2} \cdot \mathrm{DOS} \cdot V$, with $V$ being specifically the magnetic exchange impurity potential, appears as the parameter characterizing the strength of the impurity in the problem of a Yu-ShibaRusinov impurity-bound state in a gapped superconductor (e.g., Ref.56).

From Ref. 37, the DOS of a single anisotropic superconducting Dirac cone in two dimensions is:

$$
\operatorname{DOS}(\omega)=\frac{2 \pi|\omega|}{\hbar^{2} v_{\|} v_{\perp}}
$$

so we need the two Fermi velocities characterizing the cone.

From our linearized dispersion we can choose the points along $k_{x}=0$ to first find the Fermi momentum at which the cone appears from the original quadratic dispersion, $\epsilon_{k_{F}}=\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{y, F}^{2}}{m}-\mu=0$ :

$$
\frac{\hbar^{2} k_{y, F}^{2}}{m}=2 \mu \approx 1 \mathrm{eV}
$$

using the band structure in Ref. 37. Using this estimate, namely $k_{y, F} \approx 0.45 \frac{\pi}{\delta}$, we can get the Fermi velocity $v_{F}$ of the original quadratic dispersion, which gives us the Fermi velocities of the cone that arises:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \hbar v_{\perp}=\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{\Delta}{h}\right)^{2}} \hbar v_{F}=\sqrt{\frac{8}{9}} \frac{\hbar^{2}\left|k_{y, F}\right|}{m}=\sqrt{\frac{8}{9}} \frac{2 \mu}{\left|k_{y, F}\right|} \\
& \hbar v_{\|}=\frac{\Delta}{h} \hbar v_{\lambda}=3 \lambda\left|k_{y, F}\right|^{2}=3 \frac{\lambda_{F}}{\left|k_{y, F}\right|}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\lambda_{F} \approx 17 \mathrm{meV}$ is the value of SOC at the FS. Plug-
ging in all numerical values (including $\hbar=6.582 \cdot 10^{-16} \mathrm{eV}$ s):

$$
v_{\perp} \approx 0.6 \cdot 10^{6} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}, \quad v_{\|} \approx 0.17 \cdot 10^{6} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}
$$

We need to fix two more parameters. First, in the discussion section we mention that an ideal measurement energy would be around $\omega=0.2 \mathrm{meV}$, which gives the final quantitative estimate of the DOS. Second, we can estimate the value for the strength of the impurity potential $\hat{V}$ by using the ones extracted from STM data on Yu-Shiba-Rusinov Fe-impurity-bound states in the fully gapped superconducting phase of $\mathrm{NbSe}_{2}$, being of order $V=100 \mathrm{meV} .[56,57]$. In total, we get the estimate for our dimensionless parameter:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{G}_{0} \hat{V} & \rightarrow \pi b^{2} \mathrm{DOS}(\omega=0.2 \mathrm{meV}) V \approx \frac{3.1}{\mathrm{eV}} 0.1 \mathrm{eV}= \\
& =0.3
\end{aligned}
$$

which is indeed smaller than 1 .

abstract:
Many systems are topologically trivial in the bulk, but still have
non-trivial wavefunctions locally in the Brillouin zone. For example, in a
small-gap Dirac material the Berry curvature is strongly peaked, but cancels
over the full Brillouin zone, while in semimetals and in nodal superconductors
there may be a lower-dimensional winding topology associated to the nodes.
Experimentally, it is difficult to directly observe such topology. We consider
general bulk Hamiltonians with nodes and chiral symmetry, extending to them the
method developed in Dutreix et al. [Nature, 574(7777):219-222 (2019)], which in
particular detected the winding around Dirac cones in graphene using charge
modulations around an impurity. We apply our method to nodal superconductors in
2d, in presence of a (non)magnetic impurity, measured by standard or
spin-polarized STM tip. We derive general conditions on the impurity scattering
and on the STM tip, expressed in terms of their preference among the two
chiralities, for when the measurement near the impurity captures the winding
difference between any chosen pair of (Bogoliubon) Dirac cones. We emphasize
the robustness of observing vortices in momentum space, in contrast to
dislocations in real space, in STM data. Testing the conditions on the
topological nodal superconductor proposed for monolayer NbSe2 under an in-plane
magnetic field, we find that spin-polarized STM on a magnetic impurity can
detect the winding of each of the 12 nodes. We conclude that a judicious choice
of impurity can be a powerful tool to determine topological quantities in 2d
superconducting systems as well as any nodal chiral system.
